story_title: The Search For Life In Extreme Environments

"Extreme environments" means places so harsh—boiling, freezing, toxic, or crushing—that most life would die instantly.<[silence:1200]>

clean_story:
"Life in hell. Scientists hunt for it. "

"Extreme environments" means places so harsh—boiling, freezing, toxic, or crushing—that most life would die instantly.

Picture a deep-sea vent: black smoke, 400°C water, no sunlight. Yet tube worms thrive there, hosting bacteria that turn sulfur into food—like a power plant inside their bodies.
Or Antarctica’s Dry Valleys: no rain for 2 million years, temperatures below -50°C. Microbes live in rocks, sipping moisture from the air.
Tools like NASA’s Atacama Rover (tested in Chile’s desert) or IceMole (a heated drill for glaciers) probe these zones.
Why? If life persists here, maybe it could on Mars’ salt flats or Europa’s ice oceans.
Tardigrades—microscopic "water bears"—survive space vacuums and radiation. Their trick? Shutting down metabolism, curling into a tun.
Panspermia. Cryptoendoliths. The Fermi Paradox.
